citeinfo.title: Black Oystercatcher Morphology and Primary Feather Lengths in Alaska and British Columbia, 2019-2022

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center

citeinfo.othercit: Suggested Citation: Roodenrijs, H., Green, D., Esler, D., 2024. Black Oystercatcher morphology and primary feather lengths in Alaska and British Columbia, 2019-2022: U.S. Geological Survey data release, https://doi.org/10.5066/P1KWBDRY

descript.abstract: These data provide morphological measurements and primary feather length measurements of Black Oystercatcher (Haematopus bachmani) captured at several sites across Alaska and British Columbia between 2019 and 2022. The first table contains mass and morphological measurements of body and bill size. The second table provides lengths of individual primary feathers measured from folded wing photographs using a computer software. These feather lengths are to be used in a size-constrained components analysis to calculate wing shape such as pointedness and convexity.
descript.purpose: These data were collected as part of a broader project studying Black Oystercatcher morphology, movement, and diet across Alaska, USA and British Columbia, Canada. Photographs of wings were taken in the field of folded wings on a board with a ruler for scale. The primary length measurements were collected using computer software analysis from wing photos.
descript.supplinf: This data release provides only measurement data of adult Black Oystercatchers. Users should be aware that other data or samples from some of the individual birds documented herein may exist. Other data may be maintained by the data collectors, published in reports and scientific articles, or available in other publicly accessible data products, such as U.S. Geological Survey data releases: Black Oystercatcher nest and diet data: https://doi.org/10.5066/F7WH2N5Q and juvenile shorebird morphological data: https://doi.org/10.5066/P9ZH3JNQ.

taxonsys.taxoncom: Taxonomy is complete for all samples. No vouchers were collected.

citeinfo.title: Latitudinal Gradients and Sex-Differences in Morphology of the Black Oystercatcher (Haematopus bachmani)
citeinfo.othercit: Roodenrijs, H., Ware, L., Rankin, C., Maftei, M., Hipfner, J.M., Robinson, B.H., Esler, D., Coletti, H., Green, D.J., 2024, Latitudinal gradients and sex-differences in morphology of the Black Oystercatcher (Haematopus bachmani). Ecology and Evolution 14(9):e70115. https://doi.org/10.1002/ece3.70115

attracc.attraccr: Individual sample IDs, collection dates, sampling locations, band IDs, and other values were cross-checked and verified with field worksheets.

dataqual.logic: Attribute values fall within expected ranges and data were proofed for the presence of duplication and omission. Blank cells or NA indicate that no data are available for a particular sample (see Entity and Attribute definitions for details).
dataqual.complete: The dataset is complete, no data were omitted.

horizpa.horizpar: Locations determined by handheld GPS; accuracy estimated to be within 5 meters.

procstep.procdesc:
FIELD:
Captures of Black Oystercatchers were conducted in spring and summer in British Columbia (March for spring, May-July for Summer) and summer in Alaska (May-July). Both active and passive capture techniques were employed using standard noose mat and noose line capture methods along with playback and decoys. Upon capture, individuals were aged by plumage and bill color and sexed by the extent of a black fleck in their iris (Guzzetti et al. 2008). Morphological measurements were taken including the length of the unflattened wing chord, tail, middle toe, tarsus, and five bill measurements (exposed culmen length, length of head and bill, bill depth and width at the end of the nares, and depth of the bill tip). Two tarsus measurements were taken for comparison, diagonal tarsus from the interstitial joint to the last leg scale before the toes and maximum tarsus length from the lower hind edge of the tibia to the heel of the foot. Photos were taken of each wing in the folded position, flattened on a board and with a ruler included for scale.

LAB:
Wing photos were analyzed in the lab to collect lengths of each primary feather using ImageJ software (Schindelin et al. 2012). The primary feathers were measured from the folded wing photos by measuring the difference between the tips of each successive feather. Due to the method of measurement, these estimated measurements include the length of the area between where the feather inserts and the top of the wing. Therefore, these measurements may be longer than others using a different technique and represent a relative primary length rather than a true length of the feather. For convenience, we refer to and label these measurements as primary lengths. Because the 9th primary is the longest, the 10th was never visible in the folded wing photos. As such, we determined the length of the 10th by subtracting the difference between primary 9 and 10 (measured in the field) from the wing length. The length of the wing as measured in the field was used as the 9th primary length. The length of primary 8 was measured by subtracting the difference between feathers 9 and 8 (measured using image) from the length of feather 9, and this process was repeated through the last primary. Due to molt, individuals were often missing several innermost primaries, and primary one was often covered by the secondary feathers. Therefore, only visible primaries and those that appeared to be full length were included in measurements. Each individual’s wing was measured twice and the average between the two estimates was included in this final dataset.

LITERATURE CITED:
Guzzetti, B.M., Talbot, S.L., Tessler, D.F., Gill, V.A., and Murphy, E.C., 2008. Secrets in the eyes of Black Oystercatchers: a new sexing technique. Journal of Field Ornithology, 79(2):215–223. https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1557-9263.2008.00167.x
Schindelin, J., Arganda-Carreras, I., Frise, E., Kaynig, V., Longair, M., Pietzsch, T., Preibisch, S., Rueden, C., Saalfeld, S., Schmid, B., Tinevez, J.-Y., White, D.J., Hartenstein, V., Eliceiri, K., Tomancak, P., Cardona, A., 2012. Fiji: an open-source platform for biological-image analysis. Nature Methods, 9(7):676–682. https://doi.org/10.1038/nmeth.2019
Stojanovic, D., Neeman, T., Heinsohn, R., 2020. Overlap in the wing shape of migratory, nomadic and sedentary grass parrots. Journal of Avian Biology 51(12). https://doi.org/10.1111/jav.02586

spdoinfo.indspref: Site names are listed to describe generalized Black Oystercatcher capture locations.

enttyp.enttypd: Table containing morphological measurements of adult Black Oystercatchers captured in Alaska and British Columbia from 2019-2022. Presented in a Comma Separated Value (CSV) formatted table.

attr.attrdef: The general location where morphological measurements were collected from the captured Black Oystercatchers.

edom.edomvd: Black Oystercatcher captured in Alaska, USA.
Black Oystercatcher captured in British Columbia, Canada.

attr.attrdef: The common geographic names for locations where morphological data were collected.

edom.edomvd: Pacific Rim National Park Reserve, British Columbia (approximately 48.88 N, 125.28 W).
Gulf Islands and Sunshine Coast Regional District, British Columbia (approximately 49.19 N, 123.65 W).
Haida Gwaii Archipelago, British Columbia (approximately 53.22 N, 132.10 W).
Kenai Fjords National Park, Alaska (approximately 59.78 N, 149.71 W).
Western Prince William Sound, Alaska (approximately 60.75 N, 147.85 W).
Kachemak Bay, Alaska (approximately 59.58 N, 151.49 W).
Katmai National Park and Preserve, Alaska (approximately 58.12 N, 154.41 W).

attr.attrdef: The coordinate that specifies the north–south position of the location where the morphological data were collected. Blank cells indicate that the latitude was not recorded.
The coordinate that specifies the east–west position of the location where the morphological data were collected. Blank cells indicate that the longitude was not recorded.
The year, month, and day when the morphological data were collected.
A code describing the season when the Black Oystercatcher was captured and morphological data collected.

edom.edomvd: Spring capture encompassing dates between February and April.
Summer capture encompassing dates between May and July.

attr.attrdef: The suffix of the metal leg band attached to each individual Black Oystercatcher at the time of initial capture.

attrdomv.udom: The suffix of the metal leg band attached to each individual Black Oystercatcher

attr.attrdef: Unique identifier of each individual Black Oystercatcher. Colored leg band with engraved alphanumeric symbols were applied to the bird. This directly corresponds to the 'Alpha' attribute in table "BLOY_wingMeasurements_AlaskaBC.csv" included with this data release.

attrdomv.udom: Unique identifier of each individual Black Oystercatcher.

attr.attrdef: The age class of the individual Black Oystercatcher. Age class was determined based on plumage, bill color, and eye color.

edom.edomvd: After second year; individual bird was in 'adult' plumage and had a bright red and yellow bill as well as a bright yellow iris.
Second year; individual bird had both adult and retained juvenile plumage. Bill dull to bright red with distinct dark tip and iris brownlish to dull yellow.
Third year; individual bird was in 'adult' plumage but had dusky brown tinge to bill and iris dull to bright yellow.

attr.attrdef: Assignment of the size of the black eye fleck found in the iris(s) of each Black Oystercatcher, based on Figure 1 in Guzetti et al. 2008. If two codes are assigned, this suggests that each eye had different sized flecks. Blank cells indicate that an eye fleck size was not assigned.

attrdomv.udom: Assignment of the size of the black eye fleck found in the iris(s) of each Black Oystercatcher, based on Figure 1 in Guzetti et al. 2008.

attr.attrdef: Biological sex of individual Black Oystercatchers. Sex was determined based on eye fleck score, where females have larger eye flecks (category 2b-3c; Guzzetti et al. 2008), and males have smaller eye flecks (category 1a-2a; Guzzetti et al. 2008). Those with intermediate eye flecks (category 2) were assigned sex based on sex of mate and culmen length.

edom.edomvd: Identified as a male Black Oystercatcher.
Identified as a female Black Oystercatcher.

attr.attrdef: Initials of the person who banded and measured the Black Oystercatcher.

edom.edomvd: Hannah Roodenrijs
Lena Ware
Brian Robinson
Cole Rankin
Mark Maftei
Jesse Kemp

attr.attrdef: The body mass (grams) of an individual Black Oystercatcher. Blank cells indicate that the body mass was not recorded.

The length (millimeters) of the wing of an individual Black Oystercatcher measured from the bend (i.e., wrist joint) to the tip of the longest primary feather. Measurements refer to the length of a folded, unflattened wing. Blank cells indicate that the wing length was not recorded.

The length (millimeters) of the tail of an individual Black Oystercatcher measured from where tail feathers enter body to the end of the longest feather. Blank cells indicate that the tail length was not recorded.

The length (millimeters) of the longest (middle) toe of an individual Black Oystercatcher measured from the base of the toe to the tip of the toe, nail not included. Blank cells indicate that the toe length was not recorded.

The length (millimeters) of the diagonal tarsus of an individual Black Oystercatcher measured from the interstitial joint to the last leg scale before the toes. Blank cells indicate that the diagonal tarsus length was not recorded.

The length (millimeters) of the maximum tarsus of an individual Black Oystercatcher measured from the lower hind edge of the tibia to the heel of the foot. Blank cells indicate that the maximum tarsus length was not recorded.

The length (millimeters) of the culmen of an individual Black Oystercatcher measured from the tip of the bill to the first feather on the upper mandible using calipers. Blank cells indicate that the culmen length was not recorded.

The combined length (millimeters) of culmen and head of individual Black Oystercatcher measured from the tip of the bill to the back of the Occipital crest. Blank cells indicate that the head bill length was not recorded.
The depth (millimeters) of the bill at the distal end of the nares of an individual Black Oystercatcher. Blank cells indicate that the bill depth was not recorded.
The width (millimeters) of the bill at the distal end of the nares of an individual Black Oystercatcher. Blank cells indicate that the bill width was not recorded.
The height (millimeters) of the tip of the culmen of an individual Black Oystercatcher. Blank cells indicate that the bill tip was not recorded.

attr.attrdef: Biological sex of individual Black Oystercatchers. Sex was determined based on eye fleck score, where females have larger eye flecks (category 2b-3c; Guzzetti et al. 2008), and males have smaller eye flecks (category 1a-2a; Guzzetti et al. 2008). Those with intermediate eye flecks (category 2) were assigned sex based on sex of mate and culmen length.

edom.edomvd: Identified as a male Black Oystercatcher.

edom.edomvd: The length of P2 could not be determined or was not recorded.

attr.attrdef: The length (millimeters) of the 7th primary feather of the wing of a Black Oystercatcher. See the 'Process Steps' section for an explaination of calulating primary feather lengths.
The length (millimeters) of the 8th primary feather of the wing of a Black Oystercatcher. See the 'Process Steps' section for an explaination of calulating primary feather lengths.

The difference (millimeters) between the tip of the ninth primary (longest) and the tenth primary feather on the wing of an individual Black Oystercatcher.
Name of the image from which the primary feather lengths were derived from.

attrdomv.udom: Name of the image from which the primary feather lengths were derived from.

enttyp.enttypd: Folder containing digital photographs of wings from capture Black Oystercatchers. The main folder contains subfolders with reference to each region where the images were taken. File naming convention: BLOY_wing_[ALPHA CODE]_[YYYYMMDD]: where ALPHA CODE = the Alpha Code corresponding to the attribute 'Alpha' in table "BLOY_wingMeasurements_AlaskaBC.csv", and YYYYMMDD = Year, month, and day the photograph was taken.

An annotated R script for executing manovas and linear mixed models to compare the morphology of six measurements (i.e., wing, tail, toe, diagonal tarsus, maximum tarsus, and mass) between populations of Black Oystercather in Alaska and British Columbia and to test for differences in morphology between capture locations. The R script is fully annotated.

An annotated R script for executing a size-constrained components analysis with the primary length measurement document to estimate a convexity and concavity score for each individual Black Oystercacther. These scores are then put into linear mixed models to test for differences between the sexes and between Alaska and British Columbia. The R script is fully annotated.
enttyp.enttypds: Stojanovic et al. 2020 and Author defined

distinfo.resdesc: The U.S. Geological Survey, Alaska Science Center is the authoritative source and distributor of these data.
distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data for other purposes or on all computer systems, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
